title: How to write a book - Quora

response.answer_text: You’re in luck with this answer (I think). Most authors have bad habits (even no clue) about the mechanics of writing a book. I’m not going to get into the how of writing or what to write — that’s your responsibility and your expertise. Not to sound immodest, I’ve spent 35+ years in editorial, publishing and printing, and I’ve put together more than 200 books in my career. Now that I’m in financial printing, my work involves me in putting together great big hunks of those things called “IPO prospectuses” for investment bankers worldwide in a space of only 13 weeks at most. Indeed, some prospectuses of 300–400 pages that I’ve printed started from literally two sheets of paper and finished in four weeks. And paid handsomely for them. The following is “tradecraft” — and money in your pocket — so I must’ve gone bonkers to write about this. (All images via Quora image search)  THE MECHANISMATA “Begin with the end in mind.” It’s a proverb. It’s good advice. If we don’t have the end in mind, then the end won’t ever be in sight. Avoid starting anything until and unless you have a mental image of what you want as the end product. A lot of authors I’ve worked with over the years have completely FAILED in this part of the mission. They sink straight into the WRITING PART — and then end up agonising whether to put in this or that chapter, footnotes or endnotes, subheadings, appendices, picture plates and charts, you name it. And then the copyeditor and the author end up being driven up the wall by each other because so many things done had to be ROLLED BACK OR REMOVED.  STARTING POINT IS COUNTERINTUITIVE When you perk up your guts to start doing the writing, the very first step just goes against the grain of everything that you might know about writing — if you happen to live in the 21st century. Start the 1st Master Draft on paper. Wut? I’m not talking about your outlines and plans. I’m talking about the actual first-ever draft. So there you are with your brand-spanking-new laptop and an unauthorised copy of MS Office — and this loudmouth is telling you to do it on PAPER first!  FIRST DRAFT IS A MOCKUP When architects and engineers finish the planning and preliminary outlines of their designs, they do a mockup. And professional writers and designers do the same. Build your 1st Draft with placeholder pages first. Use one sheet of paper as a placeholder for every component of your ‘book.’ The outside front cover gets one sheet. The inside front cover gets one sheet. One sheet for the title page. One for the imprint. One for the foreword. And so on for each chapter, appendix, index, inside back cover, and outside back cover. There! You have your ‘book’ in skeleton form — a small pile of around two dozen sheets.  Now hand-write the wretched 1st Draft chapter by chapter. Start with the easy departments first — that usually means the middle parts of your ‘story.’ Don’t write the writeups in normal language. Write mainly in ‘telegramspeak.’ Write in normal language whenever and wherever you need to retain your own preferred phraseology. Insert into the pile every chapter or section you complete or do. The pile builds up every time you write and insert. Then you have a fearsome pile of crappy papers in a very short time. Why not just write the wretched thing on the computer and do printout? You can — it’s up to you. But I would advise you do the ‘handjob’ method for the sake of this:— At the end of your ‘master’ draft, you have a mostly handwritten draft that could be used as a support or strut that you actually wrote (literally) the thing — good for copyright proof and a defensible defence against plagiarism accusations. Now do the 2nd Draft on computer. The second draft is where your actual “authoring” takes place. When you type your handwritten master draft into the computer, I guarantee you’ll find half the stuff you wrote is just pointlessly STUPID and pure DRIVEL. While you’re typing, you’ll realise this or that part could be rewritten, rephrased, redone, re-whatever. Type that revised stuff instead. And carry on. Then do the printouts and repeat the same “piling” procedure as mentioned before. Store away your first master draft for prosperity (or embarrassment). You now have your complete 2nd Draft in printout form.  Do manual markups on the 2nd Draft. Yes, do hand markups and edits ON the 2nd Draft first. And when you type those in, also do on-the-spot computer edits. Now you print out everything — this is now your 3rd Draft.  Insert and replace updates, edits, etc, into the 3rd Draft. From the 3rd Draft onwards, every successive “draft level” pretty much resembles the handiwork in SCREENWRITING — you insert revised chapters into the pile and store away the old ones. On the COVERSHEET of your draft, you indicate the major revisions done:— DRAFT LOG 01 Jan 2017 — Master Draft 20 Jan 2017 — 2nd Draft 23 Jan 2017 — 3rd Draft 14 Feb 2017 — 3rd Draft — Chapter 7 17 Feb 2017 — 3rd Draft — Appendix 3 28 Feb 2017 — 3rd Draft — Appendix 3 (replaced whole) 03 Mar 2017 — 3rd Draft — Chapter 5 (riders) 04 Mar 2017 — 3rd Draft — Riders (various chapters) 01 Apr 2017 — 4th Draft 21 May 2017 — 4th Draft — Foreword by J. Smith (received, input) 22 May 2017 — 4th Draft — Charts (various chapters) 01 Jun 2017 — 5th Draft 03 Jun 2017 — 5th Draft — finalised as Manuscript Notice from the above Draft Log that it took our imaginary author a total of 23 weeks — because he isn’t an investment banker with a $150 million IPO deal as motivator. Whatever your writing goals are, these are the 7 steps you will have to go through to take your book idea and turn it into a professionally written book that’s ready to be published and read by readers all over the world. Step 1. Pre-Writing (Creating Your Book Template) What is pre-writing? It’s basically pre-formatting your book to look like a book in order to prepare it (and you) for success. For example, when I come up with a new book idea, I will take one of my free eBook formatting templates for fiction or nonfiction and create a new document for the book on my computer. You can download my book writing templates for free at Nonfiction and Fiction Ebook Formatting Templates for Kindle Step 2. Planning, Plotting and Outlining Your Book Planning is where you outline the basic ideas and points of your book. You can just write out the words to create a “book skeleton.” Some people spend a lot of time planning their books. They’ll even write out all the chapter titles on index cards and have sections on each index card for major points or subheadings in each chapter. That’s all fine and dandy, but for me simpler is better (and a whole lot faster). Step 3. Creative Writing It’s all about writing your ideas and thoughts on paper and letting your creativity flow unrestricted with no distractions! Don’t research. Don’t close your writing document. Don’t talk to anyone. Don’t try to edit while you type. Don’t worry about spelling. Don’t look at a dictionary. Don’t do anything that distracts you from writing the ideas down as they flow through your mind. Step 4. Revising and Editing Your Manuscript This is where you’ll thoroughly study your manuscript to find and fix any typos, grammatical errors, factual errors and other mistakes. You’ll research any facts or figures you forgot about and insert any hyperlinks and citations that you need for the book. You’ll also want to insert pictures, graphs or any other media type that you’d like to include in the book. Step 5. Getting Feedback on Your Manuscript Crowdsourcing and finding beta readers is a great way to get feedback from other people to help you improve your book. Most authors will give their book manuscript to their wife or family or friends or even a fellow author and have them review it for typos, grammatical errors, fact checking and other recommendations. That’s a wonderful way to get free advice and help on improving your book. Step 6. Professional Editing Once you’ve gone through several rounds of rewriting and revising your book and you’ve gotten feedback from your ideal readers, it’s time to hire a professional editor to help improve your manuscript even more. One of the biggest mistakes new authors make that can end up costing you a lot of money at this stage is sending a first draft to a professional editor. If you send an unedited first draft to a professional editor, they’re going to end up spending so much time on fixing typos, formatting errors, grammatical errors and common mistakes that they won’t be able to do their best work. Step 7. Formatting Your Manuscript Formatting a book manuscript is basically a simple process by which you design your document or book file to be most attractive and useful to your readers. These tips were originally posted on our blog at How to Write a Book – 7 Steps to Writing a Book That's Ready to Be Professionally Published | TCK Publishing
